captions.text: The ancient Greeks had a great idea:
The universe is simple.
In their minds,
all you needed to make it were four elements:
earth,
air,
fire,
and water.
As theories go, it's a beautiful one.
It has simplicity and elegance.
It says that by combining
the four basic elements in different ways,
you could produce all the wonderful diversity of the universe.
Earth and fire, for example,
give you things that are dry.
Air and water, things that are wet.
But as theories go, it had a problem.
It didn't predict anything that could be measured,
and measurement is the basis of experimental science.
Worse still, the theory was wrong.
But the Greeks were great scientists of the mind
and in the 5th century B.C.,
Leucippus of Miletus came up
with one of the most enduring scientific ideas ever.
Everything we see is made up
of tiny, indivisible bits of stuff called atoms.
This theory is simple and elegant,
and it has the advantage
over the earth, air, fire, and water theory
of being right.
Centuries of scientific thought and experimentation
have established that the real elements,
things like hydrogen,
carbon,
and iron,
can be broken down into atoms.
In Leucippus's theory, the atom is the smallest,
indivisible bit of stuff that's still recognizable
as hydrogen,
carbon,
or iron.
The only thing wrong with Leucippus's idea
is that atoms are, in fact, divisible.
Furthermore, his atoms idea turns out
to explain just a small part
of what the universe is made of.
What appears to be the ordinary stuff of the universe
is, in fact, quite rare.
Leucippus's atoms, and the things they're made of,
actually make up only about 5%
of what we know to be there.
Physicists know the rest of the universe,
95% of it,
as the dark universe,
made of dark matter and dark energy.
How do we know this?
Well, we know because we look at things
and we see them.
That might seem rather simplistic,
but it's actually quite profound.
All the stuff that's made of atoms is visible.
Light bounces off it, and we can see it.
When we look out into space,
we see stars and galaxies.
Some of them, like the one we live in,
are beautiful, spiral shapes, spinning gracefully through space.
When scientists first measured the motion
of groups of galaxies in the 1930's
and weighed the amount of matter they contained,
they were in for a surprise.
They found that there's not enough visible stuff
in those groups to hold them together.
Later measurements of individual galaxies
confirmed this puzzling result.
There's simply not enough visible stuff in galaxies
to provide enough gravity to hold them together.
From what we can see,
they ought to fly apart, but they don't.
So there must be stuff there
that we can't see.
We call that stuff dark matter.
The best evidence for dark matter today
comes from measurements of something
called the cosmic microwave background,
the afterglow of the Big Bang,
but that's another story.
All of the evidence we have
says that dark matter is there
and it accounts for much of the stuff
in those beautiful spiral galaxies
that fill the heavens.
So where does that leave us?
We've long known that the heavens
do not revolve around us
and that we're residents of a fairly ordinary planet,
orbiting a fairly ordinary star,
in the spiral arm of a fairly ordinary galaxy.
The discovery of dark matter took us
one step further away from the center of things.
It told us that the stuff we're made of
is only a small fraction of what makes up the universe.
But there was more to come.
Early this century,
scientists studying the outer reaches of the universe
confirmed that not only is everything moving apart
from everything else,
as you would expect in a universe
that began in hot, dense big bang,
but that the universe's expansion
also seems to be accelerating.
What's that about?
Either there is some kind of energy
pushing this acceleration,
just like you provide energy to accelerate a car,
or gravity does not behave exactly as we think.
Most scientists think it's the former,
that there's some kind of energy driving the acceleration,
and they called it <i>dark energy</i>.
Today's best measurements allow us to work out
just how much of the universe is dark.
It looks as if dark energy makes up
about 68% of the universe
and dark matter about 27%,
leaving just 5% for us
and everything else we can actually see.
So what's the dark stuff made of?
We don't know,
but there's one theory, called <i>supersymmetry</i>,
that could explain some of it.
Supersymmetry, or SUSY for short,
predicts a whole range of new particles,
some of which could make up the dark matter.
If we found evidence for SUSY,
we could go from understanding 5% of our universe,
the things we can actually see,
to around a third.
Not bad for a day's work.
Dark energy would probably be harder to understand,
but there are some speculative theories out there
that might point the way.
Among them are theories that go back
to that first great idea of the ancient Greeks,
the idea that we began with several minutes ago,
the idea that the universe must be simple.
These theories predict that there is just a single element
from which all the universe's wonderful diversity stems,
a vibrating string.
The idea is that all the particles we know today
are just different harmonics on the string.
Unfortunately, string theories today
are, as yet, untestable.
But, with so much of the universe waiting to be explored,
the stakes are high.
Does all of this make you feel small?
It shouldn't.
Instead, you should marvel
in the fact that, as far as we know,
you are a member of the only species in the universe
able even to begin to grasp its wonders,
and you're living at the right time
to see our understanding explode.

title: Dark matter: The matter we can't see - James Gillies

"Therefore, you simply cannot see something that does not reflect photons."

No, that does not follow from your definition. If p → q, it does not follow

2. Photons can not reflect other photons.
*______________________________________*
3. We don't directly see photons."


Premise 1 is wrong here. As we only see photons, it can't be true.


"The point is that by the time the signal arrives at the visual cortex, it 
is no longer a photon at all. It's some form of visual data. This data is 
what you perceive, not the photon itself. "

Sure, in the strict sense we only "see" what the brain interprets, but I 
was talking about the eye.

comments.text:
+TheLeftLibertarianAtheist 

I think we're not on the same page regarding what it means to be visible. 
You agree that being visible requires reflection of photons, correct? 
Therefore, you simply cannot see something that does not reflect photons. 
Let me lay it out in a premised argument for you:



1. Anything that can be directly seen must reflect photons.
2. Photons can not reflect other photons.
*________________________________________*
3. We don't directly see photons.


The confusion here is that what we really see is the effect of the photon, 
and this effect is whatever occurs in my brain in response to the radiation 
of the photon. 

In fact, this is how the biochemistry of sight works. Light hits your 
retina and its energy is transferred to some other form of energy in your 
rods and cones. This energy results in a signal that ultimately makes its 
way to your visual cortex. The point is that by the time the signal arrives 
at the visual cortex, it is no longer a photon at all. It's some form of 
visual data. This data is what you perceive, not the photon itself. 

Please let me know if any of this didn't make sense.
comments.author: Sam Scheidler

comments.text:
+Sam Scheidler
What? For an object to be visible it must reflect photons, yes. This is 
because we see photons. My point being made here is that we see the photons 
regardless of what happened to them before they entered our eyes.
Why can't we say that photons are visible? In order to get a mental

need to admit photons in order to visible.


"So what we can assume is that the photons interact with our retina in such 
a way as to produce unique signals in our brain. Photons with different 
properties produce signals indicating different respective colors."

We don't assume it, we know it. We know how photons cause action potentials 
to fire and how they are transmitted into the brain via the optic nerve.

comments.text:
+TheLeftLibertarianAtheist Hey guys, I feel a little clarification might be 
useful here. What Ashiq is getting at (I believe) is that we don't really 
see photons—we see colors. We can't say photons themselves are visible, 
because in order for something to be visible it must reflect photons. Thus 
you have an infinite regress (photons reflecting photons reflecting 
photons), and infinite regresses are not very useful in philosophical or 
scientific argument. 

So what we can assume is that the photons interact with our retina in such 
a way as to produce unique signals in our brain. Photons with different 
properties produce signals indicating different respective colors. 

You might want to think of it like this: Think of a vinyl record. It's 
composed of a series of ridges and bumps that produce sound. You would not 
say, however, that the bumps and ridges "sound" like anything. They're just 
properties of an object that through some manipulation can cause a sound to 
be produced.


Photons, then, are these bumps and ridges. They're not colored themselves, 
but their properties confer perceptions of color, as far as we know.

comments.text:
Dark matter is a hypothetical kind of matter that cannot be seen with 
telescopes but accounts for most of the matter in the universe. The 
existence and properties of dark matter are inferred from its gravitational 
effects on visible matter, radiation, and the large-scale structure of the 
universe. It has not been detected directly, making it one of the greatest 
mysteries in modern astrophysics﻿

comments.text:
Perhaps, like a variant of gravity, dark matter is an observable bi-product 
of the tidal forces created by the ubiquitous flow of dark energy. An 
observable resistance to flow that causes gravitational lensing. Dark 
energy causes space-time expansion and moves through space time like a 
cold, quantum fluid. This tidal force, like a current of water, affects the 
movement of objects with mass. The greater the mass an object possesses, 
the greater the resistance to flow.  Spiral galaxies are where dark matter 
is observed through gravitational lensing. The spiral arms do not fly apart 
due to this resistance where they stay intact like hurricanes or leaves 
floating in a liquid whirlpool. Scientists estimate that dark energy 
accounts for approximately 68 percent of what exists (matter and energy) in 
the known universe. Could such a large percentage of energy be a sort of a 
universal engine of the cosmos, affecting everything in its path; and 
creating motion, gravitational lensing, and dark matter? Dark matter 
accounts for approximately 27 of the mass-energy of the universe. Is it 
possible to have two unknown forces accounting for such a large percentage 
not be two tied to each other through some cause and effect relationship? 
Perhaps force is a better description since we don't know dark matter as 
actual matter but can only observe its effects. Perhaps a force is the more 
appropriate description in the same manner as gravity.

comments.text:
Can your theory explain the coronal heating problem or interstellar gas in 
extremely cold space showing emission spectra indicating a temperature of 
millions of degrees? Your theory should also be able to predict the 
ionization energies of multi- electron systems, including electron spin and 
magnetic moments, if it is accurate. It should also predict the 
acceleration of the expansion of the Universe, superconduction, the 
stability of the atom, and all physical phenomena.

QM takes 19 adjustable parameters and an arbitrary system of negating 
unwanted infinities in an ad hoc, internally inconsistent framework that 
curve fits some phenomena well but fails catastrophically for others or 
offers no explanation at all, such as "intrinsic electron spin". 

The question is how parsimonious is your model, is it self-consistent, and 
is it predictive to the limit of measurement of all physical phenomena? 

There is a theory that can explain and predict all physical phenomena to 
the limit of measurement in closed-form solutions that is simplistic, 
self-consistent, and fully consistent with all known laws and based off of 
Maxwell's Equations.

comments.text:
NO NO NO! Leucippus' idea of atoms wasn't "wrong" simply because what we 
now call atoms are divisible. He didn't say "This thing here is an atom. It 
is indivisible." His idea was simply that there is a fundamental 
indivisible unit. Atom just means "indivisible". It's not his fault that 
scientists, a couple of millenia later, looking at smaller and smaller 
things, prematurely thought they'd found the smallest indivisible unit and 
dropped his word too early on something that, as it turns out, is 
divisible. Leucippus had no access to molecules, atoms, protons or quarks 
and didn't choose which level to stop at and decide "This is indivisible." 

It may seem like a small issue in the midst of an otherwise great video, 
but when you're educating other people, please make sure what you're 
telling is correct or at least makes sense.﻿

dark matter picked up when they used the theory to predict the age of the

wilder that is why we have suns in our galaxy 4 times older than the big 
bang. i find hard to swallow both of them at the same time. dark energy is 
something exactly like dark matter. an easy explanation for something we 
cannot understand.

point being, dark matter and dark energy are like greek epicycles, fitting 
the description of an earth centered universe. point, the big bang theory 
(the mathematical father of both therms) has failed every single prediction 
in it's initial form, no matter how much we modify it's equations the 
theory and even the hypothesis is false.

Hubble and redshift: there are countless bodies out there which do not 
follow the graph of Hubble which has trends of spectroscopic data in 
correlation with light intensity (i.e. speed and distance). the real data 
is big blob of points, no clear trend, Hubble constant. in my 
opinion Hubble down right forged the data (he got addicted to success). in 
any case, he still has a place in history.

apparent redshift: intergalactic particulate matter is good at filtering 
high frequency light, bad at filtering lower frequency. in fact that low 
density medium can be a conductor for low frequency EM radiation, you can 
observe the same in acoustics via resonance studies of different materials 
at different lengths.

CMB and the bang: microwave background radiation is contrary to popular 
belief not a proof of the big bang. the big bang allows for it and that is 
just it. however, it is one of the first failure of the theory. static 
universe predictions ranged from 0.75 to 20K. bang prediction putt the 
radiation at about 50Kelvin. well, i will not point out the results, it is 
quite obvious. however, there are allot of re-estimations along the line, 
fitting the theory to the observations and new theories.

final point. if a theory needs so many readjusting in order to fit the data 
that it should be capable to predict then the theory itself is the problem. 
and at this point i seriously tend to think of cosmology as a religion if

comments.text:
Lesson by James Gillies, animation by TED-Ed.
The Greeks had a simple and elegant formula for the universe: just earth, 
fire, wind, and water. Turns out there's more to it than that -- a lot 
more. Visible matter (and that goes beyond the four Greek elements) 
comprises only 4% of the universe. CERN scientist James Gillies tells us 
what accounts for the remaining 96% (dark matter and dark energy) and how 
we might go about detecting it.

Full lesson:
http://ed.ted.com/lessons/dark-matter-the-matter-we-can-t-see-james-gillies﻿

comments.text:
La théorie du Big Bang permet de calculer le nombre de baryons de tout 
l'Univers, c'est-à-dire le nombre d'atomes d'hélium 4 et d'hydrogène, 
formés lors de la nucléosynthèse primordiale. Les astronomes en sont 
arrivés à un taux de matière baryonique d'environ 4 % de la densité 
critique. Or, pour expliquer la géométrie plate de l'Univers, la matière 
totale de l'Univers doit représenter 30 % de la densité critique (les 70 % 
restants étant de l'énergie sombre). Il manque donc 26 % de la densité 
critique sous forme de matière non baryonique ; c'est-à-dire constituée par 
d'autres particules que les baryons.

As a skeptic, I am more inclined to see dark matter as just another 'fudge 
factor' added in to make the calculations work. The only thing that says it 
should be there is that the formula that describes our understanding of 
celestial mechanics doesn't work on a galactic scale even though it works 
just fine within our solar system. Whenever you increase one variable (in 
this case distance) you can expose minute inaccuracies in other variables 
(ie: gravitational force).

Hangout with CERN every Thursday at 17:00 CET.  This week: *The Dark Side 
of the Universe*

https://plus.google.com/events/cp0e0uopa9lk0d69fedce44oh5k

Dark matter is a mysterious type of matter that no one can see but that 
makes up 27% of the content of the Universe. What is it? How do we know 
it's there? What are experiments at CERN doing to find out about it? This 
week's hangout features physicists from LHC, AMS and CAST experiments at 
CERN to talk about what they're doing to explore the "dark side" of the 
Universe....

comments.text:
The Greeks had a simple and elegant formula for the universe: just earth, 
fire, wind, and water. Turns out there's more to it than that -- a lot 
more. Visible matter (and that goes beyond the four Greek elements) 
comprises only 4% of the universe. CERN scientist James Gillies tells us 
what accounts for the remaining 96% (dark matter and dark energy) and how 
we might go about detecting it.

comments.text:
- Antiparticles are particles with the opposite charge. For example: 
electrons have -1 charge, while positrons (anti-electrons) have +1 charge. 
- Dark matter is matter that doesn't interact with other matter except 
through the force of gravity. - Dark energy is a theoretical energy used to 
explain why the Universe is accelerating in its expansion. - BTW, both Dark 
matter and Dark energy are not actually dark; they are just called that 
because we don't know what they are.
